citation.article-title: Fermentation of cinnamate by a mesophilic strict anaerobe, Acetivibrio multivorans sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Acetivibrio multivorans sp. nov.
Acetivibrio multivorans (mul.ti.vo'rans. L. adj. multus many, numerous; L.v. voro to devour, eat greedily; M.L. part. adj. multivorans devouring many kinds of substrates)
Straight to curved rods, 0.8-3.5 μm x 0.5-0.9 μm.
Occur singly or in pairs.
Motile.
Gram-negative.
Surface colonies colorless, translucent; with the size up to 2 mm in diameter, circular in form; with convex elevation and entire margin.
Chemoorganotroph.
Cinnamate, crotonate, pyruvate, sucrose, trehalose, and other carbohydrates utilized for growth.
Cellulose not utilized.
Cinnamate fermented to 3-phenylpropionate, benzoate, and acetate.
Crotonate fermented to butyrate and acetate.
Pyruvate fermented to lactate and acetate.
Carbohydrates fermented to ethanol, formate, and acetate.
A trace amount of hydrogen produced during growth on cinnamate.
A small amount of yeast extract required for growth on cinnamate.
Nitrate, sulfate, and other sulfur compounds not utilized as electron acceptors.
Strictly anaerobic.
Temperature relationships.
Growth range, 20-35°C; optimally at 30°C no growth at 15 and 40°C C.
pH relationships: growth range, 7.2-8.6 (not tested > 8.6); optimally near 7.8; no growth at 6.8.
Specific growth rate 0.81 h-1 on cinnamate under the optimal condition.
Habitat.
Anoxic sludge in an oil refinery wastewater treatment facility.
DNA base ratio. 44 mol% G + C.
Type strain.
PeC1, deposited in Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen, Braunschweig, FRG, with the deposition number of DSM 6139.
